awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FW-HTF-RM: Expanding Rural Ceramics Craft and Computational Fabrication: A Synergy
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to synergistically create new career opportunities for rural craftspeople by blending long-standing craft traditions with new computational fabrication technologies, and to develop new computational fabrication techniques inspired by craft traditions. Craft businesses keep vital cultural traditions alive, contribute significantly to regional economies, and provide communities with a sense of identity and purpose. Craftspeople and their businesses play significant roles in rural areas, where employment options are limited, and communities have a strong sense of identity and pride that is rooted in local craft traditions. Computational fabrication combines computational design, (using computer programming and algorithms to create digital designs), with digital fabrication. Computational fabrication has, thus far, been explored primarily in contexts of academic research and industrial manufacturing. However, as the availability of fabrication machines diversifies, computational fabrication grows compatible with small to medium volume manufacturing craft practices. This project will introduce computational fabrication to new constituents and broaden the development of computational fabrication technologies to represent diverse community cultural forms, values, and needs. It will engage several hundred rural craft practitioners in NM and CA with new opportunities to grow their businesses and creative practices through engagement with computational fabrication and a unique co-development process. It will also engage diverse, rural, middle- and high-school students and teachers in computation, design, fabrication, and entrepreneurship through a series of outreach activities.
The team of researchers will partner with rural craftspeople, in New Mexico and California, to co-develop new software, construction techniques, and business strategies that integrate computational design, digital fabrication, and traditional craft. The project will focus on ceramics, while working to ensure that research findings are generalizable to other craft domains. Through a methodology of workshops, interviews, and co-design residencies, the project is expected to develop transformational research contributions–involving practices, methodologies, techniques, and theory across fields–by (1) developing new forms of computational fabrication inspired by craft traditions; (2) investigating new syntheses of ceramic craft practices and traditions, community economics, HCI theory, and computational fabrication technologies; (3) exploring how the co-design and co-development of technology can integrate cultural, economic, and technological concerns; (4) applying Value Chain Analysis to ascertain the economic and cultural viability of new forms of rural production that blend traditional craft and computational fabrication; (5) developing deeper understandings of the unique challenges and opportunities facing rural craft businesses to contribute to studies across a range of fields–including developmental economics, international management, geography, and sociology–which are concerned with the increasing segregation of and inequalities between rural and urban communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant has been successful in the investigators' objectives to develop techniques and software tools for combining computational fabrication with ceramics craft.  By establishing a residency program with ceramics craftspeople, the investigators developed novel methods for the digital fabrication of functional ceramic artifacts that are compatible with the workflows and objectives of rural ceramic practitioners.

 

The residencies resulted in multiple software tools for clay and other forms of paste-based fabrication. These technologies allow for the efficient and expressive design and fabrication of artifacts with clay 3D printing technology in ways that were previously not feasible with general purpose digital fabrication tools and conventional digital fabrication materials. CoilCAM supports the combined design of parametric forms and surface textures through machine toolpaths for clay and other cementitious 3D printing applications.  SketchPath enables creators to use hand-drawn toolpaths to design for clay 3D printing. CeramWrap supports the procedural design and digital fabrication of decorative ornamentation for ceramic vessels. Paper Cut allows users to create 3D printable forms by cutting out designs from paper. Weaveslicer is a slicer designed specifically for clay 3D printing that enables designers to print a much larger range of geometry in clay than was previously possible. TRAvel Slicer is a slicing algorithm that generates tool paths with little to no travel movements, making it possible to 3D print complex geometries from clay and other paste materials. In collaboration with researchers at MIT, we also investigated the development and evaluation of new digital fabrication machines specific to clay 3D printing. We assessed the capabilities of the Digital Pottery Wheel, a polar coordinate clay 3D printer that supports the integration of manual throwing and 3D printing. We also investigated the Craft-Aligned Scanner, a clay-specific 3D scanning system that enables creators to design for clay 3D printing without using desktop computer-aided design. Finally, we developed new materials and fabrication techniques for clay and other cementitious forms of 3D printing.  Cerametal is an affordable technique for desktop metal printing using clay printers. We developed a new renewable and biodegradable material for 3D printing called  “play-dough” and corresponding custom design software that outputs instructions for loading a print tube to obtain the designed color pattern. We extended this work to develop “Clay-Dough,” a mixture of traditional clay and our custom play-dough that enables printing vessels with a controllable shrinkage rate during firing. We also developed a new 3D printable glass paste and a comprehensive firing schedule for sintering objects printed with this paste into solid glass. We developed a collection of 3D printable biodegradable materials based on different bio-wastes. We published our research in novel software, hardware, and materials for clay 3D printing in leading human-computer interaction research venues, where it has received multiple awards. SketchPath and The Digital Pottery Wheel received Best Paper awards at CHI 2024. CoilCAM received a Best Paper Honorable Mention Award at CHI 2023.  A demonstration of the collective materials, software, and hardware by the Hand and Machine Lab won an Honorable Mention Best Demo Award as well as an Honorable Mention People's Choice Award at CHI 2024, and a demonstration of the Digital Pottery Wheel won Best Demo Award at UIST 2024. 

 

In addition to fostering novel digital fabrication research, the residency provided four professional ceramic artists with extensive training computational fabrication. The work produced by residents during our residencies has been shown in prominent art galleries and Native American art venues and has been purchased by collectors. It has also won notable awards, including two first-place awards for resident Monica Silva Lovato at the Santa Fe Indian Market for two 3D-printed pots she created during her residency. To broaden the impact of our research for the ceramics craft community, we  conducted multiple business development workshops for over 75 independent ceramic craft business people in California and New Mexico. We engaged participants in activities to aid them in developing a competitive business strategy and value statements for their work while simultaneously exploring how the introduction of new technology shapes the practices and business of ceramic practitioners. To disseminate the general knowledge produced during our residencies we published two CHI papers on residency research models as a technique for software development research and the impact of computational fabrication residencies on the professional practices of Native artists and the field of Native American pottery. Our integration of emerging digital fabrication technologies with established craft disciplines enabled us to collaborate with and support people from underrepresented groups in STEM including women and Native Americans. We broadened our impact through educational engagement with graduate students, undergraduate, middle school and highschool students by developing computational fabrication courses and workshops that engaged students in computer programming and digital fabrication through the lens of functional craft production.
